column2: The old man read so much truth and so much grief in the face of the young man that he made him a sign to listen, and repeated in a low voice: "It was scarcely nine o'clock when I heard a noise in the street, and was wondering what it could be, when on coming to my door, I found that somebody was endeavoring to open it.

column2: As I am very poor and am not afraid of being robbed, I went and opened the gate and saw three men at a few paces from it.
column3: As I am very poor and am not afraid of being robbed, I went and opened the gate and saw three men at a few paces from it.

column2: In the shadow was a carriage with two horses, and some saddlehorses.
column3: In the shadow was a carriage with two horses, and some saddlehorses.

column2: These horses evidently belonged to the three men, who were dressed as cavaliers.
column3: These horses evidently belonged to the three men, who were dressed as cavaliers.

column2: 'Ah, my worthy gentlemen,' cried I, 'what do you want?' 'You must have a ladder?' said he who appeared to be the leader of the party.
column3: 'Ah, my worthy gentlemen,' cried I, 'what do you want?' 'You must have a ladder?' said he who appeared to be the leader of the party.

column2: 'Yes, monsieur, the one with which I gather my fruit.' 'Lend it to us, and go into your house again; there is a crown for the annoyance we have caused you.
column3: 'Yes, monsieur, the one with which I gather my fruit.' 'Lend it to us, and go into your house again; there is a crown for the annoyance we have caused you.

column2: Only remember this--if you speak a word of what you may see or what you may hear (for you will look and you will listen, I am quite sure, however we may threaten you), you are lost.' At these words he threw me a crown, which I picked up, and he took the ladder.
column3: Only remember this-if you speak a word of what you may see or what you may hear (for you will look and you will listen, I am quite sure, however we may threaten you), you are lost.' At these words he threw me a crown, which I picked up, and he took the ladder.

column2: After shutting the gate behind them, I pretended to return to the house, but I immediately went out a back door, and stealing along in the shade of the hedge, I gained yonder clump of elder, from which I could hear and see everything.
column3: After shutting the gate behind them, I pretended to return to the house, but I immediately went out a back door, and stealing along in the shade of the hedge, I gained yonder clump of elder, from which I could hear and see everything.

column2: The three men brought the carriage up quietly, and took out of it a little man, stout, short, elderly, and commonly dressed in clothes of a dark color, who ascended the ladder very carefully, looked suspiciously in at the window of the pavilion, came down as quietly as he had gone up, and whispered, 'It is she!' Immediately, he who had spoken to me approached the door of the pavilion, opened it with a key he had in his hand, closed the door and disappeared, while at the same time the other two men ascended the ladder.
column3: The three men brought the carriage up quietly, and took out of it a little man, stout, short, elderly, and commonly dressed in clothes of a dark color, who ascended the ladder very carefully, looked suspiciously in at the window of the pavilion, came down as quietly as he had gone up, and whispered, 'It is she!' Immediately, he who had spoken to me approached the door of the pavilion, opened it with a key he had in his hand, closed the door and disappeared, while at the same time the other two men ascended the ladder.

column2: The little old man remained at the coach door; the coachman took care of his horses, the lackey held the saddlehorses.
column3: The little old man remained at the coach door; the coachman took care of his horses, the lackey held the saddlehorses.

column2: All at once great cries resounded in the pavilion, and a woman came to the window, and opened it, as if to throw herself out of it; but as soon as she perceived the other two men, she fell back and they went into the chamber.
column3: All at once great cries resounded in the pavilion, and a woman came to the window, and opened it, as if to throw herself out of it; but as soon as she perceived the other two men, she fell back and they went into the chamber.

column2: Then I saw no more; but I heard the noise of breaking furniture.
column3: Then I saw no more; but I heard the noise of breaking furniture.

column2: The woman screamed, and cried for help; but her cries were soon stifled.
column3: The woman screamed, and cried for help; but her cries were soon stifled.

column2: Two of the men appeared, bearing the woman in their arms, and carried her to the carriage, into which the little old man got after her.
column3: Two of the men appeared, bearing the woman in their arms, and carried her to the carriage, into which the little old man got after her.

column2: The leader closed the window, came out an instant after by the door, and satisfied himself that the woman was in the carriage.
column3: The leader closed the window, came out an instant after by the door, and satisfied himself that the woman was in the carriage.

column2: His two companions were already on horseback.
column3: His two companions were already on horseback.

column2: He sprang into his saddle; the lackey took his place by the coachman; the carriage went off at a quick pace, escorted by the three horsemen, and all was over.
column3: He sprang into his saddle; the lackey took his place by the coachman; the carriage went off at a quick pace, escorted by the three horsemen, and all was over.

column2: From that moment I have neither seen nor heard anything."
column3: From that moment I have neither seen nor heard anything."

column2: D'Artagnan, entirely overcome by this terrible story, remained motionless and mute, while all the demons of anger and jealousy were howling in his heart.
column3: D'Artagnan, entirely overcome by this terrible story, remained motionless and mute, while all the demons of anger and jealousy were howling in his heart.

column2: But, my good gentleman, resumed the old man, upon whom this mute despair certainly produced a greater effect than cries and tears would have done, "do not take on so; they did not kill her, and that's a comfort."
column3: But, my good gentleman, resumed the old man, upon whom this mute despair certainly produced a greater effect than cries and tears would have done, "do not take on so; they did not kill her, and that's a comfort."

column2: Can you guess, said d'Artagnan, "who was the man who headed this infernal expedition?"
column3: Can you guess, said d'Artagnan, "who was the man who headed this infernal expedition?"

column2: I don't know him.
column3: I don't know him.

column2: But as you spoke to him you must have seen him.
column3: But as you spoke to him you must have seen him.

column2: Oh, it's a description you want?
column3: Oh, it's a description you want?

column2: Exactly so.
column3: Exactly so.

column2: A tall, dark man, with black mustaches, dark eyes, and the air of a gentleman.
column3: A tall, dark man, with black mustaches, dark eyes, and the air of a gentleman.

column2: That's the man! cried d'Artagnan, "again he, forever he!
column3: That's the man! cried d'Artagnan, "again he, forever he!

column2: He is my demon, apparently.
column3: He is my demon, apparently.

column2: And the other?"
column3: And the other?"

column2: Which?
column3: Which?

column2: The short one.
column3: The short one.

column2: Oh, he was not a gentleman, I'll answer for it; besides, he did not wear a sword, and the others treated him with small consideration.
column3: Oh, he was not a gentleman, I'll answer for it; besides, he did not wear a sword, and the others treated him with small consideration.

column2: Some lackey, murmured d'Artagnan.
column3: Some lackey, murmured d'Artagnan.

column2: Poor woman, poor woman, what have they done with you?
column3: Poor woman, poor woman, what have they done with you?

column2: You have promised to be secret, my good monsieur? said the old man.
column3: You have promised to be secret, my good monsieur? said the old man.

column2: And I renew my promise.	And I renew my promise.
column3: true

column2: Be easy, I am a gentleman.
column3: Be easy, I am a gentleman.

column2: A gentleman has but his word, and I have given you mine."
column3: A gentleman has but his word, and I have given you mine."

column2: With a heavy heart, d'Artagnan again bent his way toward the ferry. Sometimes he hoped it could not be Mme.
column3: With a heavy heart, d'Artagnan again bent his way toward the ferry. Sometimes he hoped it could not be Mme.

column2: Bonacieux, and that he should find her next day at the Louvre; sometimes he feared she had had an intrigue with another, who, in a jealous fit, had surprised her and carried her off.
column3: Bonacieux, and that he should find her next day at the Louvre; sometimes he feared she had had an intrigue with another, who, in a jealous fit, had surprised her and carried her off.

column2: His mind was torn by doubt, grief, and despair.
column3: His mind was torn by doubt, grief, and despair.

column2: Oh, if I had my three friends here, cried he, "I should have, at least, some hopes of finding her; but who knows what has become of them?"
column3: Oh, if I had my three friends here, cried he, "I should have, at least, some hopes of finding her; but who knows what has become of them?"

column2: It was past midnight; the next thing was to find Planchet.
column3: It was past midnight; the next thing was to find Planchet.

column2: D'Artagnan went successively into all the cabarets in which there was a light, but could not find Planchet in any of them.
column3: D'Artagnan went successively into all the cabarets in which there was a light, but could not find Planchet in any of them.

column2: At the sixth he began to reflect that the search was rather dubious. D'Artagnan had appointed six o'clock in the morning for his lackey, and wherever he might be, he was right.
column3: At the sixth he began to reflect that the search was rather dubious. D'Artagnan had appointed six o'clock in the morning for his lackey, and wherever he might be, he was right.

column2: Besides, it came into the young man's mind that by remaining in the environs of the spot on which this sad event had passed, he would, perhaps, have some light thrown upon the mysterious affair.
column3: Besides, it came into the young man's mind that by remaining in the environs of the spot on which this sad event had passed, he would, perhaps, have some light thrown upon the mysterious affair.

column2: At the sixth cabaret, then, as we said, d'Artagnan stopped, asked for a bottle of wine of the best quality, and placing himself in the darkest corner of the room, determined thus to wait till daylight; but this time again his hopes were disappointed, and although he listened with all his ears, he heard nothing, amid the oaths, coarse jokes, and abuse which passed between the laborers, servants, and carters who comprised the honorable society of which he formed a part, which could put him upon the least track of her who had been stolen from him.
column3: At the sixth cabaret, then, as we said, d'Artagnan stopped, asked for a bottle of wine of the best quality, and placing himself in the darkest corner of the room, determined thus to wait till daylight; but this time again his hopes were disappointed, and although he listened with all his ears, he heard nothing, amid the oaths, coarse jokes, and abuse which passed between the laborers, servants, and carters who comprised the honorable society of which he formed a part, which could put him upon the least track of her who had been stolen from him.

column2: He was compelled, then, after having swallowed the contents of his bottle, to pass the time as well as to evade suspicion, to fall into the easiest position in his corner and to sleep, whether well or ill.
column3: He was compelled, then, after having swallowed the contents of his bottle, to pass the time as well as to evade suspicion, to fall into the easiest position in his corner and to sleep, whether well or ill.

column2: D'Artagnan, be it remembered, was only twenty years old, and at that age sleep has its imprescriptible rights which it imperiously insists upon, even with the saddest hearts.
column3: D'Artagnan, be it remembered, was only twenty years old, and at that age sleep has its imprescriptible rights which it imperiously insists upon, even with the saddest hearts.

column2: Toward six o'clock d'Artagnan awoke with that uncomfortable feeling which generally accompanies the break of day after a bad night.
column3: Toward six o'clock d'Artagnan awoke with that uncomfortable feeling which generally accompanies the break of day after a bad night.

column2: He was not long in making his toilet.
column3: He was not long in making his toilet.

column2: He examined himself to see if advantage had been taken of his sleep, and having found his diamond ring on his finger, his purse in his pocket, and his pistols in his belt, he rose, paid for his bottle, and went out to try if he could have any better luck in his search after his lackey than he had had the night before. The first thing he perceived through the damp gray mist was honest Planchet, who, with the two horses in hand, awaited him at the door of a little blind cabaret, before which d'Artagnan had passed without even a suspicion of its existence.
